body: This is very strange. Did you verify that torch_module.cc actually compiled?
I added a bracket in torch_module.cc, ran make clean_all and make -j8 and mxnet still compiles correctly
Are you sure you can use mx.symbol.TorchModule? Can you do a search under mxnet root for 'TorchModule'? Looks like the plugin is not activated at all. What's your config.mk setting?

USE_CUDA=1
USE_CUDA_PATH=/usr/local/cuda
USE_CUDNN=1
USE_BLAS=atlas
USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 1
USE_S3=1
USE_TORCH = 1
TORCH_PATH = /home/ubuntu/torch

It's stale. Check make/config.mk and update. We are using MXNET_PLUGINS flag instead of USE_TORCH now.
Like this:

```

#----------------------------
# plugins
#----------------------------

# whether to use torch integration. This requires installing torch.
# TORCH_PATH = $(HOME)/torch
# MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/torch/torch.mk

# whether to use sframe integration. This requires build sframe
# git@github.com:dato-code/SFrame.git
# SFRAME_PATH = $(HOME)/SFrame
# MXNET_PLUGINS += plugin/sframe/plugin.mk
```
Ok. I think this confusion is caused by out dated tutorial. I'm going to update it.

Thanks. I now have another error when I compile:
#########
In file included from plugin/torch/./torch_base.h:21:0,
                 from plugin/torch/torch_base.cc:7:

##########

When I look at /home/ubuntu/torch/install/include/THC/ I see the following files:
ubuntu:~/torch/install/include/THC$ ls
generic         THCDeviceTensor.cuh           THCDeviceUtils.cuh     THCReduceAll.cuh         THCStorage.h     THCTensorMath.h
THCAllocator.h  THCDeviceTensor-inl.cuh       THCGeneral.h           THCReduceApplyUtils.cuh  THCTensorConv.h  THCTensorRandom.h
THCApply.cuh    THCDeviceTensorUtils.cuh      THCGenerateAllTypes.h  THCReduce.cuh            THCTensorCopy.h  THCTensorSort.h
THCBlas.h       THCDeviceTensorUtils-inl.cuh  THC.h                  THCStorageCopy.h         THCTensor.h
Try adding `-I$(TORCH_PATH)/install/include/TH -I$(TORCH_PATH)/install/include/THC` to CFLAGS in plugin/torch/torch.mk
Yes! It works now :)
Thanks a lot for your help!

@Gelu74 Thank you for you reply. After I generate the `test.lst` and `test.rec` following this method. I would like to load my previously trained model to predict the labels for these testing data. 

```
model = mx.model.FeedForward.load(...)
test_dataiter = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
    path_imgrec = args.data_dir + "test.rec",
    mean_r      = 121.75,
    mean_g      = 122.54,
    mean_b      = 122.51,
    rand_crop   = False,
    rand_mirror = False,
    data_shape  = data_shape,
    batch_size  = args.batch_size,
    )

pred = model.predict(test_dataiter)
print pred
```

I am expecting that `pred` is a list of predicted labels showed on the screen. However, my program get stuck. Do you have any idea how to fix that ?
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3724085/12377620/91507a00-bd5e-11e5-848f-39c8f78e78e4.png)

Well, I guess it depends on your network configuration but usually predict would return a vector of probabilities for each image giving the probability of belonging to each class.
For how long does it get stuck? if your test dataset is large and you are not using a gpu, prediction could take long... try with a reduced test set with very few examples.
you might want to look at the kaggle data science bowl example, I have made a pull request to incorporate prediction, you can have a look at the code at:
https://github.com/Gelu74/mxnet/tree/master/example/kaggle-ndsb1

@antinucleon Could you please detail "The image iterator will automatically calculate/load mean file if you set mean_file=mean.nd."? How to write an image iterator to have such functionality?

```
    train_dataiter = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec = args.data_dir + "train.rec",
        data_shape  = data_shape,
        batch_size  = args.batch_size,
        rand_crop   = True,
        rand_mirror = True,
        shuffle     = True, # Note that it will only shuffle in the batch!
        num_parts   = kv.num_workers,
        part_index  = kv.rank)
```

Besides, will the `mean_image` or `mean_r, mean_g, mean_b` also be conducted on the validation and testing data? The document says that they are only augmentation parameters. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3724085/12377662/266f89fe-bd60-11e5-9072-beb3fbd9d770.png)

@Gelu74 That's great! Thanks for providing this "new version" of ndsb1. Actually I attended this competition last year after learning the CNN for 1month. I only got 191th, using Lasagne. One more question, do you have any idea how to automatically compute the `mean_image` or `mean_rgb`?
Thank you @tqchen ! I'll check it out.

I am actually a marine biologist with interests in image classification for thing very similar to ndsb1, a newbie to deep learning. 191th is not bad, any insights you would share?
As for the mean_image, if you specify:
    train = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(                                                     |
        path_imgrec = args.data_dir + "train.rec",                                     |
        mean_img    = args.data_dir + "mean.bin",  ...
and there is no such file, mxnet will automatically generate the mean image for you, look at the cifar10 example.

I observe that without cudnn cpu and gpu works concurring. With cudnnV3 divergence is the most and with cudnnV4 results are more similar. However cudnnV3 gives the best speed, 94 samples/sec for 32 batch size of inception net . cudnnV4 82 samples/sec  and without cudnn 57 samples/sec. In the end, speed and reliability has reverse move.

(2) The code you have run and the error message.

(3) The R `sessioninfo()`

Sorry. stupid mistake. i just realized that i was copying in R code in python. sorry. i come from a R background, and just in a hazy state of mind didnt realize my mistake. stupid mistake. is there a python example as well? Saw this https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/callback.py but let me know if I should look somewhere else.

Apparently it can be solved if you put cudnn & opencv & BLAS dlls in the Anaconda's site-packages folder. The problem is that libinfo.py only gives info about the libmxnet, that depends on these three libraries that are not being copied.
Have you checked #1274 ?

just a simply code like this:

``` python
import argparse
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np
import logging
import symbol_fcnxs

workspace = 1536
ctx = mx.cpu()
def load_checkpoint(prefix, epoch):
    save_dict = mx.nd.load('%s-%04d.params' % (prefix, epoch))
    arg_params = {}
    aux_params = {}
    for k, v in save_dict.items():
        tp, name = k.split(':', 1)
        if tp == 'arg':
            arg_params[name] = mx.nd.array(v.asnumpy(), ctx)
        if tp == 'aux':
            aux_params[name] = mx.nd.array(v.asnumpy(), ctx)
    return (arg_params, aux_params)

def main():
    fcn8s = symbol_fcnxs.get_fcn8s_symbol(21, workspace)
    fcn8s_args, fcn8s_auxs = load_checkpoint(args.prefix, args.epoch)
    save_callback = mx.callback.do_checkpoint("FCN8s_VGG16-new")
    save_callback(args.epoch-1, fcn8s, fcn8s_args, fcn8s_auxs)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description='training pascal voc segmentation using fcn-16s.')
    parser.add_argument('prefix', default='FCN8s_VGG16',
        help='The prefix(include path) of vgg16 model with mxnet format.')
    parser.add_argument('epoch', type=int, default=19,
        help='The epoch number of fcn16s model.')
    args = parser.parse_args()
    main()
```

The C++ api development is here: https://github.com/hjk41/MxNet.cpp
It is almost complete, and we will merge it back to dmlc/mxnet after some
clean up

@Gelu74 Thank god! You have make things clear for me. I actually read through the cifar10 when I was using mxnet for the first time. I was being wondered where the "mean.bin" came from and how to generate it from a image list. It turns out that it will be compute automatically. And Gelu, the document says the `mean_img` or `mean_rgb` are augmentation parameters. But, as far as I understand, they are used for normalized purposes so that the optimization process would be easier. What's your thought ?

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3724085/12381722/b6681f8e-bdca-11e5-8e28-7234f3987a18.png)
Thanks for your response about BatchNorm.

I would say that it is a parameter to the augmentation since it can be substracted to each augmented image and hence it should be passed as a parameter to the augmentation function. But I do know nothing about the insides of mxnet.
This is now unrelated to your original issue, you might get better amswer if you close this one and open a new issue.

you need exe.forward(is_train=True).
Dropout is only activated in training.
delete the executor and the ndarraies you used to create it.
thank you :)
@Gelu74 Thank you Gelu74. I have learned a lot from you !
I copied these dlls , and issue still exists.

It works, the solution is below.

1st:
python build & install success
2st:
copy all dependence dlls(opencv,openblas etc.) to C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg\mxnet\
3rd:
before import mxnet add mxnet package path to PATH environment.
os.environ['PATH']=r'C:\Python27\Lib\site-packages\mxnet-0.5.0-py2.7.egg\mxnet;' + os.environ['PATH']

this is my stup steps about  install mxnet in centos 5.8,may can help you~, however, you should read code cafefully  before you install.
#!/usr/bin/env bash

###### pre env

cd /home
mxnet_path='install_mxnet'
if [  -x "$mxnet_path" ]; then 
  rm -rf "$mxnet_path"
fi 
mkdir "$mxnet_path"

cd install_mxnet
yum -y install git
if [ "$?" == "0"]; then
  echo "git install fail"
  exit 0
fi

######update gcc to 4.8.2
new_gcc='/opt/rh/devtoolset-2/root/usr/bin/gcc'
cd /etc/yum.repos.d
wget http://people.centos.org/tru/devtools-2/devtools-2.repo
yum -y install devtoolset-2-gcc devtoolset-2-binutils devtoolset-2-gcc-c++
if [ ! -f "$new_gcc" ]; then
  echo "gcc install fail"
  exit 0
fi
mv -f /usr/bin/gcc /usr/bin/gcc.bak4.1.2
mv -f /usr/bin/c++ /usr/bin/c++.bak4.1.2
mv -f /usr/bin/g++ /usr/bin/g++.bak4.1.2

ln -s /opt/rh/devtoolset-2/root/usr/bin/gcc /usr/bin/gcc
ln -s /opt/rh/devtoolset-2/root/usr/bin/c++ /usr/bin/c++
ln -s /opt/rh/devtoolset-2/root/usr/bin/g++ /usr/bin/g++
cd -

######install atlas
libcblas='/usr/lib64/atlas/libcblas.so'
rpm -ivh http://mirrors.yun-idc.com/epel/5Server/x86_64/epel-release-5-4.noarch.rpm
yum -y install atlas-devel
if [ ! -f "$libcblas" ]; then
  echo "atlas install fail"
  exit 0
fi
ln -sf /usr/lib64/atlas/libcblas.so /usr/bin/libcblas.so

######upgrade python
new_python='/usr/local/bin/python2.7'
wget https://www.python.org/ftp/python/2.7.9/Python-2.7.9.tgz
tar -xzf Python-2.7.9.tgz
cd Python-2.7.9
./configure
make
make install
if [ ! -f "$new_python" ]; then
  echo "python update fail"
  exit 0
fi
mv /usr/bin/python /usr/bin/python2.4.3
ln -s /usr/local/bin/python2.7 /usr/bin/python
sed -i 's/#!\/usr\/bin\/python/#!\/usr\/bin\/python2.4.3/g'  /usr/bin/yum 
yum -y groupinstall 'Development Tools'
yum -y install openssl-devel\* ncurses-devel\* zlib*.x86_64
yum -y install bzip2 bzip2-devel bzip2-libs
cd -

######install numpy
wget http://sourceforge.net/projects/numpy/files/NumPy/1.10.2/numpy-1.10.2.tar.gz
if [ "$?" == "0" ];then
  echo "numpy download fail"
  exit 0
fi
tar -xzf numpy-1.10.2.tar.gz 
cd numpy-1.10.2
python setup.py build
python setup.py install
cd -

######install mxnet
git clone --recursive https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet
if [ "$?" == "0" ]; then
  echo "mxnet download fail"
  exit 0
fi
cd mxnet
cp make/config.mk .
sed -i 's/USE_OPENCV = 1/USE_OPENCV = 0/g' config.mk  
sed -i 's/USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 0/USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 1/g' config.mk
sed -i 's/wget/wget\ --no-check-certificate/g' ps-lite/make/deps.mk
make -j4
Looking into it. Possible bugs introduced in recent PRs

It seems as though it doesn't have a Windows build yet anyways, so calling it as a TorchModule is probably the correct approach for now. 

Closing for now.
Try to modify the value of `fix_gamma` in BatchNorm from defaulted True to ''False'', since the default value is changed in recent commits.

I am still struggling on how to access the logged information for further analysis.

In the R implementation ( #511 ) - one could add an extra argument (err) to the call_back function, and then later on access this (e.g. head(err)). That does not work in Python. Could anyone help me to understand how one could do a similar thing in Python? Ideally i would like to get the vector output of the error log - to e.g. use that information for plotting, etc.

This is definitely an issue that should be fixed.

But you don't have to hotfix the mxnet code to use the Adam optimizer.
It's also possible to provide an optimizer object instead of a string:

``` python
model = mx.model.FeedForward(
        ctx           = [mx.gpu(0)],
        num_epoch     = 60,
        symbol        = network,
        optimizer     = mx.optimizer.Adam(),
        initializer   = mx.init.Xavier(factor_type="in", magnitude=2.34))

model.fit(X=data_train)
```
After fixing the code and re-installing the python package, it worked. I think  I tried providing an  optimizer object but that didn't work.
CUDA is propietary to NVIDIA, I don't think it would run in a non-nvidia graphics card

em, the installation document needs some special section about CentOS installation since many packages have different names that those in Ubuntu/Debian, so it is not a simple replacement of 'apt-get' and 'yum', just like in your log:

```
mirrors.hustunique.com 310 packages excluded due to repository priority protections Setting up Install Process No package build-essential available. Package git-1.7.1-3.el6_4.1.x86_64 already installed and latest version No package libatlas-base-dev available. No package libopencv-dev available. Nothing to do
```

In short, your log shows that, neither atlas/openblas nor opencv was installed. Please double check with google search for how to install these two packages in CentOS.

@Shashidhar123 One can rent an AWS GPU instance and try by following my recent blog for setup MXnet there 
https://no2147483647.wordpress.com/2016/01/16/setup-amazon-aws-gpu-instance-with-mxnet/ 0.07$ per hour is not so expensive.

Can you show the AMI ID of your AWS? And, libdc1394 error is just a trivial one, and one can disable it by `sudo ln /dev/null /dev/raw1394` If you want to set up your new AMI from scratch, please follow my recent blog https://no2147483647.wordpress.com/2016/01/16/setup-amazon-aws-gpu-instance-with-mxnet/

that is good to know. the remainder of the code works fine - so will just disable libdc1394. for what it is worth - I had previously used ami-55deaf30 (which supposed to have caffe and cuda installed, but i had trouble getting this AMI to run with Mxnet). Did a clean reinstallation, and now everything is working well

one thing that you might want to add to your blog is that folks might want to make their AWS persistent (if they use spot instances). Secondly, they might have to add an additional EBS Volume to store the data. My instance was not big enough in base storage capacity to accomodate the files. If helpful - i am happy to send the code / instructions on how to attach / mount an EBS drive.

@hjk41 Thanks for that. One question about the use_ndarray.cpp example: it looks like we are required to manually perform arithmetic to index into the array. Seems error prone and labor intensive. And dangerous too in that it means client code must have knowledge of the internal representation of the NDArray, and is coupled to it. Is there any intention to provide something like the Caffe Blob's offset() or data_at() methods? I didn't notice anything like that in ndarray.h or MxNetCpp.h..
@WDee please send the github link to your code and I will update the blog (with special thanks and link to your github)
@rfarouni I think it's worthwhile to make a pr for this issue. Would you like to pr?

Good suggestion. I will add a work item for this.

Can we just feed the (80000,1000) label array to mxnet model using mxnet.io.NDArrayIter ?

I had the same problem, and finally I figured it out. I used Dependency walker to analyze the .dll and found many missing API-MS-WIN-CORE DLLs. Then I recalled that before compiling mxnet, I firstly had to install MS C++ Compiler Nov 2013 CTP, which, however, couldn't be installed until the conflicting Visual C++ Redistributable 2013 were uninstalled. Hence, I reinstalled it and collected all the dependent DLLs. It worked.

@zhangchen-qinyinghua  thanks for your reply. How could I set the initial kernel in MXNet? I didn't find it in document.

@phunterlau. I unfortunately don't have a github account yet (somewhat new to this field) - but maybe the text and code per below is helpful for copy and paste:

Some AWS instances might not have sufficient EBS or Instance memory to download and manipulate all the data. In that case, one could choose to launch a seperate EBS volume and attach this to your instance. The instructions below show how to do this: 
- Go in your EC2 management console to the Volumes tab in the Elastic Block Store (this should show in the dashboard on the left side of your screen as well)
- Press create volume and select and launch an EBS volume with sufficient size (e.g. 150GB)
- Attach this volume to your Instance
- Now log in to your instance (e.g. with Putty) to insert the next commands on the command line / bash: 
- The command "lsblk" should show you the volumes linked to your instance. your new drive should appear - but is potentially not attached to your instance
- To mount this drive you want the following the excellent instructions on http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ebs-using-volumes.html 
- For the purpose of this tutoral - you want to move the new drive on the directory data (assuming that this data does not exist yet and has no data in it (or put differently, that you are not overriding any existing data that you want to keep)

In python, I think it should be write in this way but I don't test yet. This is just a pseudo code. 

```
# real param
data_nd = ...
w_np = np.ones((3, 3)).reshape((1, 1, 3, 3))
w_nd = mx.nd.array(w_np)
# symbol
data = mx.sym.Variable("data")
weight = mx.sym.Variable("weight")
conv = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, weight=weight, no_bias=True, kernel=(3,3), num_filter=1, num_group=3) 
# note cudnn doesn't support group
# alternative: use mx.sym.SplitChannel
# bind
executor = conv.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args={"data":data_nd, "weight": w_nd}, args_grad=None, reqs=None)
```

I am using your cifar10 example. Here is the new code:

``` python
def  fun1(**args1):
    if args1['dim_match'] == True: # if dimension match
        conv2 = conv_factory(data=args1['data'], num_filter=args1['num_filter'], kernel=(3,3), stride=(1,1), pad=(1,1), act_type='relu', conv_type=0)
    else:
        conv2 = conv_factory(data=args1['data'], num_filter=args1['num_filter'], kernel=(3,3), stride=(2,2), pad=(1,1), act_type='relu', conv_type=0)
    pool = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=conv2, kernel=(7,7), pool_type='avg')
    flatten = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=pool, name='flatten'+ str(args1['i']))
    fc = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=flatten, num_hidden=args1['num_classes'],  name='fc' + str(args1['i']))
    if args1['first_module'] == True:
        softmax = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc, name='softmax'+ str(args1['i']))
    else:
        softmax2 = args1['softmax']
        softmax1 = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc, name='softmax'+ str(args1['i']))
        softmax = softmax2 + softmax1
     return conv2,softmax
def main(data,num_classes,n)
    args1 = {'data':data, 'num_filter':16, 'dim_match':True,'num_classes':num_classes,'first_module':True}
    for i in range(n):
        args1['i'] = i
        if i==0:
            data,softmax = fun1(**args1)
        else:
            args1['first_module'] = False
            args1['softmax'] = softmax
            args1['data'] = data
            data,softmax = fun1(**args1)
return softmax
```
